fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: The world wide web and not the internet was born in the Cern laboratories (Eternal wonder of humanity's first great achievements, page 21, March 10). The internet began as a US military project that connected different and distant computer networks. The web is an application which allows users to navigate within and between documents using internal connections, or hyperlinks. Brooklyn Bridge links Manhattan to Long Island and not to "the mainland", as we had it in yesterday's leader, In praise of ... the Sydney Harbour Bridge, page 34. The City of London Polytechnic is now London Metropolitan University and not London Guildhall University (Penny Newman profile, page 33, March 9). London Guildhall merged with the University of North London in 2002. A short report headlined Skydiver falls to death as parachute fails to open, page 10, March 9, early editions, wrongly said the man had fallen 30,090 metres and wrongly converted this to 10,000 ft (it is 98,720 feet). In fact the fall was 10,000 ft, which is 3,048 metres. A photograph of David Bowie's 1970 wedding to Mary Angela Barnett (Angie), which accompanied a panel headlined From the sublime ... page 6, G2, March 7, was wrongly credited to Bromley Press. The copyright belongs to the Kentish Times. A death notice for Betty Joan Overin misspelt her late husband Roy's first name as Reg (page 37, March 10). Apologies to the Overin family and friends. · It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning +44 (0)20 7713 4736 between 11am and 5pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding public holidays.
